title: lear-again-music-of-nonsense-poet-to-be-heard-again-after-more-than-100-years
story: Edward Lear, who lived from  to , is best known as a nonsense poet and author of The Owl and the Pussy-cat, but he was also a composer.Dr Sara Lodge, from the University of St Andrews School of English, has recorded all the music that Lear wrote or re-worded, including many of the songs that he sang in public and musical settings of his nonsense poems that he knew and approved of in his letime.The project marks the first time that all of Learrsquos works have been recorded.Many have not been heard for more than  years.A series of six concerts of Learrsquos words and music will take place, where Dr Lodge will be performing alongside pianist, David Owen Norris, and operatic tenor Mark Wilde.The concert series begins in Scotland, at the Society of Musicians in Edinburgh on  March, and as part of StAnza, Scotlandrsquos international poetry festival in St Andrews, on  March.Dr Lodge said: "Learrsquos music deserves to be much better known."His beautul setting of Tennysonrsquos Tears, Idle Tearsrsquo is very moving."It compares very well with settings of the same poem by Arthur Sullivan and Ralph Vaughan Williams."Itrsquos also true that most of Learrsquos nonsense poems are actually songs, which Lear would have sung to music he improvised at the piano."She added: "Sadly, of his nonsense repertoire, we only have his music for The Pelican Chorus and The Courtship of the Yonghy-Bonghy-Bo, but we know that he sang The Owl and the Pussy-cat to his friends and many of his other works. "He invented musical characters like The Dong with a Luminous Nose and even musical-sounding plants like the Bong-tree and Stunnia Dinnerbellia."Lear visited Scotland in .Some of his limerick characters come from Scottish destinations.This include the lsquoYoung Person of Ayr Whose head was remarkably squarersquo, the lsquoOld Person of Skye  who waltzrsquod with a Bluebottle flyrsquo and the lsquoOld Person of Fe  who was greatly disgusted with lersquo.The National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh holds a collection of Learrsquos work, with a cache of  watercolours.Dr Lodgersquos new book, Inventing Edward Lear, is an account of Learrsquos relationship to the intellectual, social and cultural le of his times.

title: nicola-sturgeon-rejects-wildcat-indyref2
story: The First Minister said Keith Brown had ldquomeant to say something dferent, and ruled out ever resorting to an illegal referendum, something that will disappoint Yes supporters hoping for an unofficial Catalan-style vote.ldquoIrsquove set out my position and Keithrsquos position is the same on that, she said after a video surfaced of Mr Brown, who is also the SNPrsquos campaign manager, speaking to independence activists in Aberdeen last month.He told them the UKrsquos Governmentrsquos refusal to grant Holyrood the power to hold a new vote should not be an obstacle to having one.ldquoIf we want to have a referendum, then we decide wersquore going to have a referendum.Mr Brown also revealed the First Minister feared Brexit could be ldquonormalisedthe Yes movement ldquodidnrsquot go relatively soon.He said: ldquoThat, I know, is in Nicolarsquos mind.The Tories said the comments were ldquoshocking and showed Ms Sturgeon and her team were ldquoplotting an illegal referendum.The row coincided with Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt confirming the UK Government had not changed its mind about denying a vote.He told an audience in Glasgow that ldquoof course Theresa May would reject any request for a second independence referendum.Last week Mr Brown announced the SNP should commit itself to a new Scottish currency in the event of independence.His Indyref comments were made on February  and posted on social media by the pro-independence Broadcasting Scotland website.The  referendum was based on a limited transfer of powers using a Section  order agreed by the Scottish and UK Governments.Ever since, Ms Sturgeon has held up the legally watertight process as the ldquogold standard, and said any second referendum should be based it on too.An unofficial referendum would also risk legal challenges and a Unionist boycott. Behind closed doors, Nicola Sturgeon and Keith Brown are telling party activists one thing, while telling the public quite another.ldquoIn public, they tell us theyrsquore focussed on the day job. In private, theyrsquore secretly plotting for an illegal referendum.ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos slap-down of her deputy today is a humiliation for Mr Brown.SNP MSP Bruce Crawford said: ldquoJeremy Huntrsquos comments were profoundly anti-democratic, and show the Tories now openly treating Scottish democracy with contempt ndash particularly given every area of Scotland voted to Remain.ldquoWith just  days before Brexit, Jeremy Hunt should focus on his governmentrsquos complete mishandling of Brexit.In a statement, Mr Brown said: ldquoMy position is clear ndash the deeply undemocratic stance of the UK Government in denying the mandate for indyref and refusing a Section  order should not prevent the Scottish Government seeking one and planning on the basis of winning that case.Scotland in Union chief executive Pamela Nash said: ldquoThis is yet more evidence that the SNP is determined to ignore the views of Scotland in its relentless pursuit of independence.ldquoBoth the Scottish and UK governments should respect the will of Scots, who are showing in poll after poll that they do not want another isive referendum.ldquoItrsquos time for the SNP to listen to the people of Scotland.

title: advice for supporters ahead of scottish cup game at pittodrie
story: Police Scotland officers along with partners are preparing to welcome thousands of football fans to Aberdeen for the Scottish Cup Quarter Final this Sunday.Kick off for the Aberdeen and Rangers game is at .pm and so the City Centre, Pittodrie, Aberdeen Beach and Seaton areas will be busier than usual.Police ask that fans heading to the stadium plan their journeys in advance and allow themselves plenty of extra time to get to the stadium. Match Commander Superintendent Richard Craig is encouraging everyone planning to watch the game either at Pittodrie stadium, a licensed premises or in their home to enjoy the match but to behave responsibly. He said: “It is well-documented that drinking too much alcohol can lead you to become more vulnerable to becoming involved in crime either as a victim or perpetrator. I am urging supporters to behave responsibly and be aware thatyou’re drunk you won’t be allowed entry to the stadium and you’ll miss the match. “Anyone who does become involved in disorder or any act of violence will be dealt with robustly. “Additional officers will be on duty across the North East and within the stadium on Sunday and they will be supported by specialist resources. Our officers are extremely experienced in policing football matches and will be able to offer assistance should anyone need it.“Although the new AWPRis an option for travel we would still advise all football traffic coming from South of Aberdeen to use the traditional supporters’ route into the city .“We are here to ensure the safety and security of all supporters attending the game and minimise disruption to the local community. "I would remind supporters that those entering Pittodrie will be closely monitored for possession of alcohol or pyrotechnics of any kind. It is a condition of entry to the ground that fans allow themselves to be searched and those who refuse will be turned away by the club. “We will be implementing policing operations throughout the day, including spot checks on buses and coaches travelling to the game."Superintendent Craig added: “Pyrotechnics are extremely dangerous and endanger the safety of those around you as well as your own safety. title: new premises for support firms
story: Aberdeenshire-based oil field equipment suppliers, Cable Solutions Worldwide Ltd and ESWL, are expanding their businesses and moving their head offices to Blackhall Industrial Estate in Inverurie.With support from a six-figure funding package from Royal Bank of Scotland, the recently completed office, co-owned by the companies, will allow the leading design and manufacturers of bespoke cable solutions to expand into the international oil and gas market.Cable Solutions Worldwide Ltd provides both off-the-shelf and bespoke design, manufacturing, supply and project management facilities to the oil and gas, subsea, ship building and renewable energy sectors.It is hoped the larger, purpose-built space will increase productivity and allow the firm to take on more staff, in addition to widening its product reach.ESWL, a procurement company to the local and international energy sector, also hopes to expand its sales and engineering team in the next year.Colin Fraser, director of Cable Solutions Worldwide, said: “We’ve come through a relatively turbulent period within the subsea and oil and gas sectors and are now looking to expand into more robust markets.“The purpose-built facility will allow us to increase the cable assembly process, provide more erse products, stock more of our customers’ favourites and provide jobs to the local economy.”Iain Dougary, director of ESWL, added: “It’s positive to see other north east businesses growing and confidence ing to the sector. Our new Inverurie premises will allow us to strengthen our existing team, by hiring new team members in our sales and engineering workshop.”Martin Ramsay, relationship director at Royal Bank of Scotland, said the move is indicative of growing confidence in the industry. He said: “The growth plans of both companies are prime examples of confidence ing to the oil and gas sector within Scotland, benefitting the local economy.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"CE marking after Brexit"  CE marking after Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: golden celebrations for couple
story: An Ellon couple have celebrated their golden wedding anniversary, marking  years together.Bill and Isobel Bonner reached the milestone on Friday, March .The couple first met at the Victoria Hall in Ellon, but Bill first dated Isobel’s sister before eventually asking his future we out.Isobel said: “My sister didn’t mind us being together, she ended up being one of my bridesmaids.”The pair were together for three years and engaged for two before marrying at Dyce Parish Church on March   when Isobel was  and Bill was .Bill originally hails from the Tarves area, and Isobel from Oldmeldrum, but the couple made the move to Ellon in January .Through the years Isobel worked at the Stoneywood paper mill before working at Ellon’s former Haldanes store on the checkouts for  years, a job that she really enjoyed.Meanwhile Bill spent time working on a local pig farm and he now works as a lollypop man for Meiklemill School, and is also a part-time janitor.The couple have two sons, Mark and Robbie, and two grandchildren, Ryan and Megan.Bill and Isobel will celebrate their anniversary with close friends and family at the weekend.Commenting on their achievement Isobel said: “It is amazing but the last  years or so have just flown past.“I am the only one in my family to have reached this anniversary.”Bill added that it felt “fantastic” to celebrate  years together.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.thesouthernreporter webimage ..! title: inverurie screwfix shop is approved
story: Councillors have approved plans for the erection of a shop on the site of the former IK Motors yard on Inverurie#s Blackhall Industrial Estate.Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee heard on Tuesday that the site, which was formerly used for car sales by IK Motors, is currently unused with all sales now taking place at Highclere Business Park.The new building will be occupied by Screwfix and while the main market served by the company is trade sales, the premises would also be open to members of the public Monday to Friday from am to pm, Saturday from am to pm and Sunday from am to pm.Councillors heard that the proposal would create  jobs.The wider site currently accommodates a number of outlets including the likes of Morrisons, the Strathburn Hotel, Firework Scotland Ltd, Magpie Second Hand Furniture, William Wilson Plumbing Centre andthe Fly Cup Coffee Shop. A number of alternative sites had been discounted as a result of being either too large, too small, or unavailable.A planning report to committee stated: “The proposals would provide both local trades and members of the public with a range of DIY products from an established home improvement company and thus can be considered as a benefit to the local community.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.berwickshirenews webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Charity representatives at the launch of Run Garioch "  Charities hold last entries to Run GariochviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.berwickshirenews webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The fountain is located in Kintore Town Centre"  Summerfor Kintore fountain viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: new handbook aims to help local playgroups
story: The task of running a community based playgroup will be made easier for local groups with the publication of a free guide giving invaluable information and advice on managing their affairs smoothly.The guide, ‘Partnership for Success: a Committee Handbook’, has been prepared and published by Aberdeenshire Council and the charity Early Years Scotland, and will be launched at the Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie on Tuesday, March .The voluntary committees in charge of community playgroups can often feel overwhelmed by the demands and responsibilities of employing staff and keeping their group afloat, so the handbook is intended to help support them and enable a smooth handover for future committees.A copy of the handbook will be distributed to every playgroup in Aberdeenshire.Many of the playgroups are Early Learning and Childcarefunded providers for the local authority, and will have a vital role to play when the number of funded ELC hours parents can access for their child is doubled to , next year.The launch will bring together committee members and employees from local playgroups, alongside representatives from Aberdeenshire Council, Early Years Scotland, and local councillors.Speakers will include Jean Carwood-Edwards, Chief Executive, Early Years Scotland Laurence Findlay, Director of Education and Children’s Services, Aberdeenshire Council and Audrey Hendry, Lead Officer Education, Aberdeenshire Council.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Advice for supporters ahead of Scottish Cup game at Pittodrie viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Air traffic controllers at Wick could strike next month
story: AIR traffic controllers at Wick John OGroats Airport could go on strike next month in a bid to get an improved pay deal.They and their Highlands and Islands colleagues in the Prospect union overwhelmingly backed industrial action in a ballot.Eighty-eight per cent voted to strike, with  per cent backing action short of a strike. Turnout was  per cent.However, the union and representatives of Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdare to hold talks ndash scheduled for Friday ndash in a bid to resolve the dispute. Hial is owned by the Scottish Government.If there is no resolution then action could be taken at seven airports, including Wick John OGroats, in April and continue through the summer. Others that would be affected are Inverness, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway, Benbecula and Dundee.Prospect negotiations officer David Avery said air traffic controllers working for Hial will be taking strike action on April , although action short of a strike will start on April  and continue until August . That could include working to rosters, an overtime ban and the withdrawal of goodwill.However, the union wants to ensure there is cover for emergency incidents during any strike.Mr Avery also pointed out that Prospect members agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish Easter school holidays."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays," he said."I urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice."Air traffic controllers do not want to have to take this action but ministersrsquo refusal to engage with the issue of pay has left them with no choice. Prospect remains ready to negotiate at any point to avoid this action but ministers must come back to the table with a new, meaningful offer."Hial managing director Inglis Lyon said industrial action is likely to have "a signicant impact on passengers and the communities in the Highlands and Islands".He said: "The Prospect union has sought a double-digit pay award. As a government-sponsored agency, Hial must follow the Scottish Government pay policy. We cannot implement pay awards more than that directed by government."Mr Lyon explained that a three per cent increase was offered to all staff at the end of September. Air traffic controllers rejected the offer and want a rise thought to be around  per cent."We are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for air traffic control staff that would further bolster an attractive remuneration package that already includes excellent pension benefits and holiday entitlements," he added.Highlands and Islands MSP John Finnie, who is the Scottish Greens transport spokesman, said: "The Scottish ministers own HIAL and have a responsibility to ensure this situation is resolved urgently with a fair settlement for staff."His Conservative colleague, Edward Mountain, said: "I am disappointed HIAL air traffic controllers are considering strike action regarding their pay claim."Airports in Inverness, Sumburgh, Kirkwall, Wick John OrsquoGroats, Stornoway, Benbecula and Dundee are vital not only for businesses in the Highlands and Islands but also for holidaymakers. I urge both sides to continue to negotiate to find a solution that will prevent strike action."Meanwhile, a scheme which subsidises air fares for people in remote parts of Scotland has been extended until the end of next year.The decision to extend the Air Discount Scheme until December , , was welcomed by local MSP Gail Ross yesterday. She pointed out that from April  the scheme will cover the whole of Caithness and more areas in Sutherland.She said: "The Air Discount Scheme is not only vital to communities in the far north, but also very popular."This is a great example of the Scottish Governmentrsquos commitment to our rural communities and to widening access for local residents, encourage more visitors and also ensure more students in eligible areas are able to sign up to the scheme."The discount scheme provides travellers with a discount of  per cent on core air fares.Students studying in the eligible areas, but whose main residence is where, will also now be included in the scheme.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Barn owl numbers recover
story: CAITHNESS is considered to have the most northerly population of barn owls in the world ndash and they have recovered well after severe winters took their toll on numbers eight or nine years ago, according to RSPB Scotland.Representatives of the nature conservation charity were saddened to discover recently that a fit and healthy barn owl had apparently been killed by a vehicle in the county, but on the whole the birds are said to be doing well.Barn owls originally evolved in warm, dry climates where food is in abundance all year round. It is therefore unsurprising that barn owls in the north of Scotland have a hard time during the winter months, with peak mortality rates being between December and March due to starvation.As temperatures start to drop in winter, small mammals become less active, meaning a lot less food is available for barn owls, and they need to work extra-hard to find it. This often results in the owls being forced to feed during daylight, even though they are naturally nocturnal hunters.This lack of food is particularly dangerous for barn owls as they are poorly insulated and need more food in winter to provide them with enough energy to stay warm.The Barn Owl Trust estimates that between  and  barn owls are killed each year on UK roads.RSPB Scotland site manager Dave Jones recently sent a deceased barn owl to the Scottish Agricultural College in Thurso for autopsy, when some concerned neighbours reported it after finding it at the roadside.The results of the autopsy showed that the bird was fit and healthy, "in good shape and hunting successfully", and that the death followed trauma to its wing and abdomen ndash suggesting that the bird died as a result of being hit by a vehicle.Dave said: "It is extremely sad to discover that a fit and healthy birds le ended in this way. The barn owls in Caithness really are at the edge of their natural comfort zone and are particularly vulnerable in winter, so it isnt an unusual result, unfortunately. Its not all doom and gloom, though. Although we still find some casualties in this way, our population of barn owls in Caithness has recovered from the particularly poor winters of   and  , and they are considered to be the most northerly population of barn owls in the world."While we cant control the weather, there are some things we can do to help. If putting up a nest box, please make sure it isnt placed close to any busy roads. If you see a road casualty and it is safe to do so, please stop and report the find to your local wildle officer and to the Barn Owl Trust. This is helpful in identying accident black spots and monitoring for environmental hazards and poisons, and potential wildle crime."Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Businesses in Thurso urged to work together to help develop tourism
story: BUSINESSES must work together to help develop tourism in Thurso.That was the key message from a meeting attended by more than  people representing ious aspects of the industry, including accommodation, tours, transport and town centre shops.They met on Friday to discuss the Destination Thurso project which is being run by Thurso Community Development Trust .Last year, it conducted a community consultation which found development of tourism in the town was a priority need.The trust has since secured funding from Highland Leader and the Caithness and North Sutherland Fund to run its Destination Thurso project which employs a tourism development officer to oversee a project that will create a website, associated social media, workshops and a tourism development plan.Helen Allan, vice-chairperson of the trust, said: ldquoWe had a strong iety of dferent tourism businesses and organisations attending the meeting.ldquoI think sometimes it might be thought that tourism is only reliant on accommodation providers but that isnrsquot strictly true ndash visitors come into contact with a wide iety of services when coming to our town, from taxi drivers to town centre shops. We all have a role to play in promoting Thurso to a visitor, right down to the community who may be approached on the street by a visitor looking for directions.Fiona Carlisle, of Messy Nessy Play Centre, said: ldquoIt was brilliant to see so many local businesses coming together and being positive while looking at dferent ways to support and engage with each other regarding tourism.A Tourism Working Group for Thurso has been formed to look at ious issues, while workshops are to be run to help local people provide tourist information to visitors.Trust project officer Joan Lawrie said: ldquoThe workshops will be open to businesses for their staff and the wider public should they have an interest.ldquoWork is ongoing on the Destination Thurso website which is due to launch prior to the start of the summer season at the end of April.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Scottish Government urged to help secure future of Caithness Horizons
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to "play its part in securing a future for Caithness Horizons".It was made by local MP Jamie Stone in a letter to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and comes after talks between representatives of the museum and gallery and Highland Council.Horizons chairman Craig Brown said: "The meeting was positive in discussing possible options for long-term financial stability to allow Caithness Horizons to reopen. Further meetings are scheduled over the coming weeks."Regarding widespread concern about the future of the museum collection, Mr Brown said it "remains complete and in the same safe condition while the next steps are discussed" with the local authority.Mr Stone, the MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, described Horizons ndash which closed unexpectedly last week ndash as part of "a string of pearls" to entice visitors to the area, the others being the Castle of Mey and Dunrobin Castle.He urged the First Minister to help identy a way "to keep this vital facility open".Mr Stone said: "I was appalled to hear of this closure ndash not least because it doesnrsquot seem that long since it was first opened. Caithness Horizons has been a great success in interpreting the geology, wildle and history of the far north for local people and visitors alike. It is up to date, visually striking, full of information and everyone who has been has come away much enthused."The closure of Caithness Horizons is precisely what we cannot allow to happen and it is for this reason that the Scottish Government should play its part in securing a future for the facility."Councillor Struan Mackie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, is concerned about public statements on dispersing the collection and says that is "contrary to the founding principles of Horizons".He said any part of the permanent collection not on loan "must remain in Caithness, regardless of the future of the Horizons facility. And in the event of closure the permanent collection would revert to the Highland Council."Councillor Mackie says the local authority should explore alternative operating models and wants "a cast iron commitment to ensure our countys heritage stays in Caithness for future generations."Ian Leith, chairman of the Wick Society, which runs Wick Heritage Museum in the townrsquos Bank Row, described the closure of Caithness Horizons as "a great loss"."From a heritage point of view it is certainly important, particularly its collection which should not be broken up and dispersed," he said.Mr Leith emphasised that the heritage groups in Caithness are not in competition "but telling parts of the same story". He said: Caithness Horizons had its part to play. Now its gone it is a great loss, but hopefully it can be retrieved."He said the Thurso museum and gallery had "very dedicated and very experienced staff".Mr Leith added: "It is too important to lose, particularly its heritage collection which has a national signicance. If it was broken up it would dilute the story. Whatever the future holds, the collection must be retained."Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Slow progress on old church
story: A COUPLE who want to transform a derelict church in Castletown into their home say their plans are "progressing slowly".Angus Cowap and Dr Heather Davis purchased the th century church near the village primary school from Highland Council a year ago and have been "clearing a lot of rubbish" from the site but are now preparing for the next stage of the project.Mr Cowap said numerous consultations, studies and negotiations have been carried out and the proposals are beginning to take shape.The couple, who moved to the village three years ago, plan to replace the ruined roof and put some solar  on the south face of the building, re-glaze the windows and construct a double garage and a conservatory sun room."Internally, we will strip out the ruined fabric and make a simple open-plan living space," Mr Cowap said, stressing it will be a long-term project.He and Dr Davis moved north when she joined a medical practice in Thurso.They have spent some time clearing trees which were in danger of undermining the structure and have been shting rubbish, including rusty old cars and vehicle parts, from around the site.The church is believed to date back to  and was used by the RAF as a mess hall in World War II. It was later the site for residential caravans.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Urgent action needed after twins are born 52 miles apart
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to act on maternity provision in Caithness after a mother gave birth to twins at hospitals  miles apart.Local MP Jamie Stone described what happened as "a fiasco" and "shameful" and said it was time First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and her cabinet took action to deal with the situation.Highlands and Islands MSP Rhoda Grant raised the matter in the Scottish Parliament, while Caithness Health Action Teamsaid the case highlighted the maternity problems in the far north.Mr Stone, the Liberal Democrat MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, said: "No woman should have to face this when giving birth. It is shameful that it has taken a fiasco like this for the Scottish Government to sit up and take notice."Thankfully, the mother and both babies are healthy and we must thank the local NHS staff for their excellent work."However, this is a situation that neither the mother nor the staff should have been put in and we desperately need action from the Scottish Government."Geography and distance should not be something expectant mothers have to deal with and the government must accept that no-one should lack access to health services simply because of where they live."He spoke out after the womans ordeal was made public. She went to Caithness General Hospital in Wick in November after her waters broke when she was  weeks pregnant.It was decided she should go by ambulance to Raigmore in Inverness, over  miles away, to have her babies.But as she was near Golspie, her contractions became stronger and she was taken to the local community hospital, the Lawson Memorial, where she gave birth to a boy.A helicopter was then to take the woman to the Highland capital but was unable to land due to frost on its propellers so she made the rest of the journey by ambulance and gave birth to the second twin.Labours Rhoda Grant raised the case in parliament and claimed the air ambulance should have been called when the woman went into labour.She asked: "It begs the question why was the air ambulance or emergency retrieval team not tasked initially to airlt the mum from Caithness "Will the First Minister investigate this and will she make sure that the air ambulance treats situations like this as a priority "Nicola Sturgeon promised to investigate and asked Scotlands health secretary, Jeane Freeman, to look into it.Bill Fernie, the chairman of Chat, said the case highlighted the groups concerns about mothers having to travel to Inverness to give birth."Fortunately, we have not had a tragedy yet and hopefully we never will ndash but this underlines the fears we have had since the changes were made to the local maternity unit. There has been no risk assessment for the people who have to travel to Raigmore to have their babies."There has never been a problem with care at Caithness General or Raigmore, but mothers here should get the same kind of access to treatment as they get in the cities and we used to have here. Why in an emergency cant the experts be on call to come to Wick rather than the other way round "I hope this Scottish Government investigation comes up with some solutions to this whole problem."NHS Highland said an internal review will be carried out to consider the specic circumstances of this case.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Friday  Mar  : AM

title: government has a responsibility to resolve air traffic controllers situation says finnie
story: Highlands and Islands Scottish Green Party MSP John Finnie has said the Scottish Government and Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd have a responsibility to resolve the dispute with air traffic controllers and has offered his support to the Prospect union and its members.The Scottish Green MSP, who is his party#s spokesperson on transport, said: “The Scottish ministers own HIAL and have a responsibility to ensure this situation is resolved urgently, with a fair settlement for staff. I continue to offer solidarity and support to Prospect and its members.”The Prospect union said that, following a ballot of air traffic controllers who are members of the union,  per cent had voted for strike action, with  per cent backing action short of a strike.The dispute has come about after the pay rise was sought by the controllers, as they said they were being paid half as much as their counterparts in other areas. title: health charities call on government to provide urgent brexit details
story: Diabetes Scotland, Epilepsy Scotland, Marie Curie Scotland and the MS Society says the effectiveness of contingency plans to maintain the supply, storage and local distribution of essential medicines in Scotland will depend on all relevant agencies and authorities working in close collaboration. Speaking on behalf of the four Scottish Health charities, Angela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland said: “It’s less than four weeks until March  and people are telling us how anxious and concerned they are about the lack of clarity and detail.#As leading patient voice charities, representing hundreds of thousands of people, we have a responsibility to articulate the very real worries and fears many have about the supply, distribution and storage of medicines in a no deal Brexit.“Insulin, for example, is a daily le-saving necessity for thousands of people with diabetes, and any delay or interruption to access would be incredibly dangerous.“Anti-epileptic drugs are also a daily necessity for people with epilepsy.#Any delay or change in the makeup of the drugmight trigger seizures in someone whose condition has been well-managed for many years with no guarantee they will be seizure free again.#Additionally, emergency rescue medication, like midazolam, is a vital lesaving drug for people with dficult to manage epilepsy. Any interruption to supply raises serious concern and may result in avoidable deaths.“There are many other drugs and medical supplies which are equally critical to health.“We are urgently calling on the Scottish Government to produce the detail required to reassure the Scottish public that all relevant organisations involved in the supply, storage and local distribution of medicines in Scotland, have robust systems and agreements in place.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur presses government on fair ferry funding
story: Responding to news that government funding for Orkney’s leline ferry services has decreased by £, since last year — leaving a shortfall of £,, — Orkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur has again pressed the Scottish Government to honour its commitments to fair ferry funding.Mr McArthur is concerned that Orkney Islands Council will be forced to implement a three per cent rise in fairs. He questioned Minister for Public Finance, Kate Forbes MSP, in the Scottish Parliament earlier this afternoon, Wednesday, asking how this shortfall squares with the government’s commitment to the principle of fair funding for our leline internal ferry services.According to the Orkney MSP, the minister responded by saying that the government recognise the challenges in running these ferry services and that they have been clear in their budget that adequate funding is to be delivered.Commenting after the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “We now know that the Scottish Government has cut funding for Orkney’s internal ferry services by £, compared to last year.  This has left a £.m shortfall in the Council’s budget for delivering these leline services.#It is baffling how Ministers think this approach is consistent with their commitment to the principle of fair ferry funding.  It certainly flies in the face of the will of parliament, which voted for the government to deliver on its earlier promises.“Meantime, the island communities that rely on these leline services are left picking up the tab, including a three per cent increase in fares this year.  Ministers may ‘recognise’ the challenges of running these services, but they also must recognise their obligations genuinely to provide adequate funding.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: northern isles msps raise hial strikes with scottish government
story: Orkney MSP, Liam McArthur, and Shetland MSP, Tavish Scott, have raised the impending HIAL air traffic control strike with the Scottish Government.Mr McArthur has said he wrote to the transport secretary, Michael Matheson MSP, demanding that he: “do everything possible to bring both sides together in a bid to avoid this damaging industrial action taking place”, saying that, “the potential disruption . . . any such action is likely to have on leline services to from Orkney and other airports affected would be signicant”.Meanwhile, Mr Scott will seek to raise these concerns with First Minister later this week.The two Northern Isles MSPs said: “There is absolutely no doubt that any industrial action on these routes would be hugely damaging to our island communities. From isles patients attending hospital appointments to local businesses trying to remain competitive, these services are a genuine leline.“Even at this late stage, we would urge HIAL and the unions to get back round the table and resolve this dispute.  Ministers must also do everything possible to help broker a resolution and avoid the massive disruption any airport closures would inevitably cause.#Following Friday#s announcement from the Prospect union, that air traffic controllers under their membership had voted to undertake industrial action, HIAL said, as a government-sponsored agency, they had to follow the Scottish Government pay policy, and could not implement pay awards more than that directed by the government.A Scottish Government spokesman has since weighed in on the situation, saying: “HIAL has implemented a pay rise for all staff, which is a signicant improvement on previous years, as well as signicantly increasing their contribution to their pension scheme in order to maintain this benefit for employees. Staff also continue to receive generous annual leave, sick pay and other allowances.“In the face of the UK Government’s continued budget cuts, the Scottish Government delivered a distinctive and progressive Pay Policy for   — one which is fair, supports those on lower incomes and protects public sector jobs and services while delivering value for money for the people of Scotland.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Community hub expansions set to bring jobs boost
story: Hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of grants have been secured to build the facilities at the Smith Hub on the outskirts of Lochcarron.The Lochcarron Community Development Companyhopes to be able to start soon on the pound, contract at the Smithy Hub on community woodland once the necessary paperwork is signed.LCDC chairman Colin Sharp said there are four funding bodies involved and the grants total pound,.ldquoItrsquos all been agreed in principle and we will announce where the funding is coming from later.ldquoBut this will be going ahead. The project involves the redevelopment and extension of an underutilised building at the hub which is currently used as an office and a gallery for craft and art work.ldquoThe board are excited about this development which will also bring new jobs to the area.The new facility will provide a social space for the local community and visitors alike and will be called Cafeacute Ceardach, .ldquoIn keeping with one of the main aims of LCDC this will initially create five much-needed employment opportunities with the intention to extend this to seven positions within  months.ldquoIt will also secure a much-needed revenue stream to enable the other projects and aspirations of LCDC to be progressed, including the provision of affordable housing and skills development opportunities.He said the company was grateful to the grant bodies for their help and local businesses for their support.ldquoThe new facility will be open all year round with a view to providing locally-sourced produce for both retail sale through our delicatessen and also be used to create the menu of the cafeacute.ldquoOur retail space will provide a shop window for local artists and craftsmen and craftswomen. This will further enhance the footfall and income opportunities for other outlets at the Smithy Hub site.And to embrace a ldquogreen, low food miles agenda electric vehicle charge points will be provided.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Date set for Highland air traffic controllers strike
story: Air traffic controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airport Limitedare set to strike on April , affecting operations at Inverness Airport as well as in Dundee, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Members of the Prospect union will also take action short of a strike between April and August , in a continuing disagreement over their pay offer for -.This will include instruction to work to rosters an overtime ban and withdrawal of goodwill though Prospect says it will seek to agree a protocol with Hial to ensure cover for emergency incidents.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoProspect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.ldquoI urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Gairloch sitooterie volunteers are hailed for transforming area
story: VOLUNTEERS who helped transform a coastal swathe of gorse-dominated wasteland near the pier in Gairloch into a popular visitor attraction have been acknowledged for their efforts.Keep Scotland Beautulrsquos Itrsquos Your Neighbourhood scheme rates initiatives to improve the natural environment for everyone to enjoy.The ldquoSitooterie created along a stretch of road now offers visitors and locals alike access to benches with a pleasant outlook across the water.Thanks to the efforts of volunteers and donations from well-wishers and local businesses, the area is also largely wheelchair-accessible and also boasts a quirky boat feature which has been a hit with local children.The assessment says locals have taken the area to their hearts since the first bench was located there.Sitooterie coordinator David Carruthers said: ldquoThis is a terric tribute to the whole community who have so involved themselves in this project either with ideas, finance or especially practical involvement.ldquoThe assessment is an amazing recognition of the dedicated work done by so many supporters.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: PARENTS and teachers have been asked to consult on a change to Easter Holiday dates that would move them to the first two weeks of April each year.Highland Councilrsquos care and learning service will run the engagement through head teachers, parent councils, local negotiating committees for teachersand other relevant parties in the region.Committee chairman Councillor Andrew Baxter said: ldquoOther local authorities are already following the model of a set school Easter holiday and officers understand from early discussions that some head teachers are keen to move to this proposal.Local authorities in Scotland must set their own school term dates and in-service days to ensure that schools are open for  pupil days and five in-service days each year while Easter Friday and Monday would remain days off.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Inverewe access upgrade to aid felling
story: A FOREST access at Inverewe Gardens could be used as a temporary loading area for timber after the National Trust for Scotland announced plans to cut down some of its mature trees.The trust has lodged a planning application to upgrade the access and form a parking loading area.ldquoThe temporary facility is required to assist in the harvesting of  tonnes of commercial timber in the forest, said the trust in its planning application. ldquoThe timber has reached maturity and is now ready for harvesting and any delay may result in the timber being susceptible to wind blow.ldquoIt is proposed to improve the entry and exit transition on the existing access area and create a new parking area for trucks with a small timber stacking area. Following the extraction of the timber the stacking area will be landscaped to merge into the surrounding area.The access, which is  metres north-east of the gardensrsquo restaurant on the Poolewe to Aultbea road, is currently used for access and as a felled forest area.Surface water will be directed away from the public road and contained on-site through the use of silt traps and soak away.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Resurfacing to aid A9 safety
story: DRIVERS are set to face disruption on the Tain bypass when more than half-a-kilometre of the A is resurfaced later this month.Some pound, is to be spent on the improvements, which will take place across both junctions where the B meets the A.Work will get under way on March  and will take place at night for five nights between the hours of pm and am.The project will also install improved road markings and road studs, including the addition of a double white line system through the junctions, further improving road safety.The A will remain open throughout the works, however, to ensure the safety of road workers and motorists temporary traffic lights and a mph convoy system will be in place.Although work will not be carried out during the day, a reduced mph speed limit will be in effect during those hours owing to the temporary nature of the surface.And during the first three nights of works, the Tain south junction will be closed during working hours to allow the project to be undertaken safely. A ersion route onto the B via the Tain north junction will be in place. Outwith working hours the junction will be reopened.Traffic sign improvements along the bypass will be implemented in the spring and early summer of this year as a separate project to further enhance road safety in the area.Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotlandrsquos North West Representative, said ldquoWe have taken steps to increase the safety for motorists at this junction with the addition of a double white line system, and further traffic sign improvements will begin later this year as part of a separate project.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Site manager near four times the limit
story: And the blunder will have a major knock-on impact for the man.Fiachra OrsquoConnor, of Gordon Terrace in Invergordon, drove home from a local pub while nearly four times over the legal drink-drive limit.The -year-old site manager was disqualied from driving for a year and fined pound when he appeared at Tain Sherf Court on Monday.OrsquoConnor admitted committing the offence on December  last year at the townrsquos Bank Street, High Street and Albany Road.Tain Sherf Court heard police came across OrsquoConnor at .am on the day in question.Tests taken at .am showed him to have  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The limit is .Roderick Urquhart, prosecuting, said: ldquoHe had forgotten to put his lights on and was stopped by police. He drove the car from a pub car park through a iety of residential streets to his home.Defence agent Ken Ferguson said his client had gone to the pub around .pm intending to have a drink and then walk home.Mr Ferguson told the Court: ldquoHe stayed for longer than intended and did not leave the pub until closing time by which time he had consumed more alcohol.He went on: ldquoHe made the error of judgement that he would take the car back to the house ndash a decision he regrets.The court was further told that OrsquoConnor typically drives around , miles a year on business.Speaking in mitigation, Mr Ferguson said that the loss of his licence would inevitably make it dficult for OrsquoConnor to carry out his employment obligations.Mr Ferguson urged Sherf Chris Dickson to take as lenient a view as possible as to theof the disqualication in light of this fact.Sherf Dickson agreed that OrsquoConnor could get a three-month discount on the driving banhe successfully completed a drink-drive rehabilitation course.Friday  Mar  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: poorest scots pensioners face devastating 7000 a year blow
story: Thousands of Scotland#s poorest pensioners who are in a #mixed age couple# could stand to lose out on around # a year when new UK Government changes to Pension Credit come into force in May.The move by the UK Government was investigated today by the Scottish Parliament’s Social Security Committee, where the national charity for older people Age Scotland gave evidence about the “devastating impact” it will have.Mixed age couples affected are those where one is below pension age and one is in receipt of a low state pension.Pension Credit tops up the state pension to £ a week for a single person and £. for a couple. The Universal Credit rate, which would be applicable for new mixed age couple applicants, is around £ a week. The dference is around £ a year for those on the lowest incomes.The move was quietly announced through a Written Ministerial statement on a busy Brexit vote day in the UK Parliament in January. The new changes will go in effect on th May .: Pensioner poverty rate higher in Scotland than rest of UKUntil now, mixed age couples will be able to choose whether they claim Pension Credit or working age benefits. However, from th May, a couple will have to wait until they both reach their State Pension Age in order to claim Pension Credit.Those who are not able to be on Pension Credit will also lose out on cold weather payments, housing benefit, Council Tax Reduction, social fund funeral payments and may not be entitled to the warm home discount.: Pensions review launch to boost pots for retirement Commenting on the new policy, Age Scotland’s Chief Executive, Brian Sloan said: “This outrageous new policy will have a devastating impact to Scotland’s poorest pensioners and will make older couples of mixed age poorer for living together. When the move was announced the UK Government did not know how many people it would impact. Weeks later it emerged that it would impact , people in  , , the following year and , the year after that, but still no official assessment for Scotland.“We estimate that at least  of the poorest pensioners in Scotland will be hit next year and double that the following year. It’s not acceptable.“The health of Scotland’s most vulnerable pensioners will be harmed as they struggle to pay bills and heat their homes all because of an out-of-touch policy.“Right now, four in ten pensioner couples have dficulty paying their fuel bills and % of people over the age of  are financially squeezed. Pension credit is massively underclaimed and can help older people out of pensioner poverty which affects around , in Scotland. “We urge the UK Government to reverse this move through the primary legislation it requires as it will leave thousands of our poorest pensioners worse off. While challenging, the Scottish Government should also look at how it could mitigate against the effects of this disastrous policy.“It is vital that older people who could be entitled to pension credit, but are not already claiming it, call Age Scotland’s free and confidential phone helpline on     today. We can help with these benefits, entitlements and state pension age checks to make sure people don’t miss out .”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: first look at the jarls squad
story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. A animal skin cloak completes the look. the suit was very warm, a blessing on a day like today.If the breastplate is simple that is in contrast to the fierce-looking helmets which are designed to look like a dragon#s head, complete with #scales# hanging from the back of the helmets.Squad member Lynden Nicolson has spent hours working on the helmets and said he was thrilled with the way they had turned out. The axes are special too with the axe head crafted out of Damascus steel.Mr Nicolson was looking forward to the day ahead, saying: #It is brilliant to get here today and see everybody together. title: recruitment event planned this week
story: Major efforts to develop Shetland#s young workforce have been underway with an event planned in Mareel this week.The so-called Biggest Parents Evening is scheduled to take place on Wednesday as part of the Scottish Apprenticeship Week.It comes after a career#s event was held late last year which was attended by  employers – and was said to be an eye-opener for many of the young folk attending.Members of the council#s education and families committee heard of the events when they met in the town hall on Monday.It is hoped this week#s event could also help attract new blood to the teaching profession.Director of children#s services, Helen Budge, said two young teachers were due to be on hand to provide information to anyone thinking of teaching as a career-path.Information should also be on hand to encourage people thinking of going into childcare through the modern apprenticeship scheme – a profession which has seen a growth in numbers as the council rolls out its expansion of entitlement hours in early learning.SIC director of children#s services Helen Budge #A lot of young folk said they did not realise the range of employment here in Shetland, and there were some things they had not even thought of doing, so that was really helpful,# Mrs Budge said.A report before members showed a number of social work vacancies during the last quarter, forcing the service to take on agency staff.Questioned by central councillor Davie Sandison, Mrs Budge said the service was encouraging engagement with careers events to help combat the dficulties experienced.Recent efforts have focused on moves to #grow your own# staff, but Mrs Budge said Shetland was also being promoted through social media.#We have, in the past, gone to colleges and universities and been part of their career events,# she added.Religious representative, Martin Tregonning, said it could be worth combining forces with other bodies, such as the NHS, to share the costs of attending other career events on the mainland. raquo..

title: recycling shed expected to open in july
story: The much discussed sorting shed for recycling at Gremista is set to open in July, the SIC environment and transport committee heard at a meeting on Monday.Shetland South councillor George Smith posed the question regarding the progress of the shed to the infrastructure services department during the meeting, to which waste management team leader Colin Bragg replied that a deadline of July had been set for staff to move into the long-mooted sorting shed.The current recycling scheme started in the North Mainland in March last year, and was rolled out sporadically throughout the isles over the next few months, ending with Lerwick which started recycling in October. title: council seeks views on detailed knab plans

title: full fibre broadband for the north isles
story: Schools and health centres in the North Isles could see high-speed internet connections installed in the next  months.Shetland Islands Council has secured almost £ million from the UK government to extend the council’s existing fibre network to Yell and Unst.It will fund a network of broadband connections between public sector buildings across Yell and Unst. This will include schools and care centres and health centres. The £. million investment should open up possibilities for video-linked working such as online learning and telemedicine.The funding is being provided by the department of digital, culture, media and sportand is aligned with the Scottish government’s Reaching  per centnetwork in Unst and Yell, which expects to extend superfast fibre access to most premises in the area.It has been welcomed by the council#s development committee chairman Alastair Cooper.“This is good news for the North Isles, who have historically suffered from poor broadband and connectivity, while other parts of Shetland have seen upgrades,# he said.#This is a positive improvement for public services in Yell and Unst, which lays a foundation of connectivity that can be extended to domestic and business premises in the future. We hope that the R initiative will help deliver domestic and business connectivity in the near future too.”For full story, see Friday#s Shetland Times.Astonishing ongoing costly stupidity by the Council re fast broadband for all the islands. An earth station with local microwave links could have provided this twenty years ago. A merger and cooperation between the Council,the numerous government agencies , the NHS and take over of local telecoms to have provided a local provider with virtuous public and private benefits, with profits staying locally. Due to all the previous piece-meal attempts and investment, it is of course entirely possible thatthis opportunity has long sailed.The lack of vision, creativity and cooperationby officers, elected members, the MSP and MP is truly staggering...

story: A pilot travel scheme is due to be rolled out next month to help young people in low income families achieve their potential in arts or sports.The council project – outlined by head of the SIC#s development department, Neil Grant – will aim to give assistance to youngsters who would not normally afford travel costs to the mainland.Mr Grant told elected members a £, budget was required for the one year project.It is hoped the pilot will encourage more young people to take part in physical or cultural activities.
